Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Ebonite Hour

In ebonite feed heat-set hour  
Beware the frotch of gloamy fray  
Its wompish jaws of stony might  
And flits at eve to slurp the day  

The stout quester hears a clanging  
Of gear on gloom-horn belt and steel  
He dons burnglove and glassjacket dank  
And grips a flameforger’s zeal  

Then far on crimson meadow stept  
The frosted shape of spindleshade  
It hissed a sizz and crackle leapt  
From iron tusks and nightly blade  

He lunged with flamestitch beam in hand  
And smote the frotch with spurfire-brand  
It borked and spurted, flame unplanned  
Its brizzle-blood in scorch-spray fanned  

Now home he strides with ringing cheer  
His burden light, his purpose clear  
The realm revived in dawn’s bower  
In ebonite feed heat-set hour

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "hollow grind on an O1 blade". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Hollow-Grind Wyrm

1  
Beware the hollow-grind on blade,  
Where steely sparks and shadows play;  
From mettle’s mire the edge is made  
To sip the strand of mortal fray.  

2  
He seized his strop and whetstone bright,  
To buff the flank and calm each side;  
He muttered murkfare rune of might,  
And honed against the raving tide.  

3  
Behold the grindhob, grim and grey,  
Its charnished scales alert to sting;  
It lunged in flash to seize the fray,  
A moan of hissing, chittering.  

4  
He raised the O1 with grave heed,  
And slashed a scar across its pride;  
It hissed and welled its crimson bleed,  
Then staggered ’neath his sharpened guide.  

5  
He turned with heart of stern delight,  
His O1 gleamed in midnight’s glide;  
He strode beneath the waning light,  
To hearth and hall, his foe aside.  

6  
Thus ends the tale of shavings fine,  
Of steely edge and sable blade;  
But mark ye well the brash design—  
Beware the hollow-grind on blade.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "forged leaf scroll". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
Forged Leaf Scroll

In the greenlit grove where mournful bells toll  
Men warn of power in the Forged Leaf Scroll  
Its glyphs will steal the stoutest heart’s soul  
And summon gnarble-wisps to dance and troll  

I seized my sinewed sword by waxwhisp bright  
And brushed my cloak with brimstone-forged might  
My heart sang falter through the moonlit night  
As thorn-pronged dread dared me to stand and fight  

It loomed, two ember-eyes with glimmer-vex gleam  
Then “crak-oh!” rang deep through midnight seam  
Its quill-shards hissed and skittered in moon’s beam  
A sweeping fang array that stole my dream  

I lunged with yew-forged blade and heard it clang  
The steel sang true in one swift silver swing  
A soulquake split its bone-cold armor rang  
As crimson torrents burst in fateful ring  

At dawn I left that greenlit grove once more  
With Fang of Gloom and sealed Forged Leaf Scroll  
The dread that clung to dusk dissolved before  
Yet still they warn, “Beware the Forged Leaf Scroll”

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "kiln witness cone bend". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Kilncone

1.  
Beware the Kilncone’s burnished bone,  
That stalks the red-glow wastes at night;  
No kiln witness braves its searing tone,  
Nor shrinks from ember-bending light.  

2.  
Equip thy kiln-forged guard of steel,  
And clasp the weldwraith’s ashen blade;  
Let sinew quake where fear would feel,  
To brave that scorching masquerade.  

3.  
Through bristle-bolts of embered smoke,  
Thy brittle heart may quake and tire;  
As pyro-roots in darkness choke,  
And cinders drown in funeral fire.  

4.  
Then from the cinder-thicket’s grip,  
Springs forth the beast with coal-black stare;  
Its spired cone shall sund’ring rip,  
Bold souls that wander unaware.  

5.  
Yet steel that hisses, sparks, and gleams,  
Shall meet the blaze with thunderous clang;  
O hearth-born hero, rouse thy dreams—  
Strike true until the echoes hang.  

6.  
Beware the Kilncone’s burnished bone,  
While dawn ascends with victor’s flame;  
Home from the cinder’s crushing zone—  
Beware the Kilncone’s burnished bone!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "lead type in a composing stick". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Glyphwyrm and the Compos-Stick

1  
Beware the glyphwyrm’s hungry eye,  
That slurps the lead in rows aligned;  
It slinks through page with tinsel cry,  
And steals the molds we’ve tightly lined.  

2  
To guard your glyphs, arm stick in hand,  
And snug the sorts with sluggle-click;  
Let tachyzing align the band,  
While clink and clack form rhythm thick.  

3  
The typewright’s bold heart goes thrum-thrill,  
As flicker-flash of sorts align;  
Yet shadows slick with hush and chill  
Await the slip of flawed design.  

4  
From brambly space the glyphwyrm slouched,  
Its gnarled jaws aglint with lead;  
It sputters slosh, its signets crouched,  
To snag the words that minds have bred.  

5  
He hefted stick, his courage high,  
And glimmer-geist aglow with grace;  
He thrust the sort to break its lie,  
Then clang and clash made creature pace.  

6  
Now safely stowed each shining row,  
The sorts align where fonts can grow;  
Return lead type to compos-stick,  
And slay the glyphwyrm’s sly old trick.

info.topic: lead type in a composing stick

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "urushi lacquer cure". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Urushi Lacquer Cure

Beware the sly urushi lacquer cure,  
That seeps at dusk across the floor;  
Its seeping glaze will ne’er be sure,  
Till shadows wail forgotten lore.  

He dons his bristled gloves and grips his blade tonight,  
Then pours a draught of lumilac so bright;  
He drips its glaze in meandering gloss-flight,  
And hums a drim of courage, starry sight.  

From brume and brim a urushwyrm did call,  
Its shardfire scales aflame with fevered loom;  
It hissed a noxious hiss of venom-fed brawl,  
Then rolled its hornéd helm of spurning doom.  

He hewed the urushwyrm with vorphin blade,  
It shrieked, it shattered in crackling flame;  
Then sliced its heart till ember-ire unmade,  
And quenched the raging ruin in arcless fame.  

Now dawn unfolds the grain with ghostly gleam once more,  
The felled remains of fear lie hushed before the scourge;  
A soft hum swells the heart, ascent of triumph-roar,  
Beware the sly urushi lacquer cure.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Plum-Brown Blueing Bathwyrm

1  
Beware the plum-brown blueing bath!  
Its suds enmesh in tangling froth;  
Resist its swirl of brume and froth,  
And shun its drench from sudsy cloth.  

2  
He clasped his foambane staff with care,  
And donned his tarnished glazeplate rare;  
With glint of sudscore all alight,  
He strode into the brume of night.  

3  
The bathwyrm lurked in sudgy gloom,  
Its plum-brown hide in blueish bloom;  
It hissed a hissle with low hum,  
Its sud-bound tail tolled like a drum.  

4  
He felt a wash of bath-brume round,  
That soupy torrent swung and bound;  
It muffled foot and dulled his stride,  
Though valour swelled his inmost tide.  

5  
Then splish–splosh! sudspear shone with gleam,  
He lunged ’gainst bathwyrm’s wrathful stream;  
A clash of brists and gloop resound,  
A foam-snap echo cleft the ground.  

6  
The sudwyrm felled with final chuk,  
Its bathy roar in silence stuck;  
He grasped the foam-scar shorn of yore,  
And tramped the sud-swept path once more.  

7  
He came from bath-brume path anew,  
His heart afire with foamy dew;  
His father cried in gleeful wrath,  
Beware the plum-brown blueing bath!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "farewell at a platform". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Farewell at the Platform

1  
Upon the dusk-lit platform ground,  
The rail-horns gasped their ghostly drone;  
A fate, they hiss, will soon be found  
Within the wraith’s unblinking tone.  

2  
With faregood cloak and glimstone brand,  
He steels his heart ’gainst shadow-shade;  
He feels the chuff of ghostly gland,  
And grips his gleaming steamforged blade.  

3  
Sudden, the Whistlewraith appears,  
Its sneerwisp sighs like mournpuff air;  
It clacks and clatters ’cross the gears,  
And sows the hush of dark despair.  

4  
He thrusts his blade with gleaming will,  
A shing and ping split yawning gloom;  
The Wraith, undone, lets terror spill,  
Then fades ’neath dawn’s roseate plume.  

5  
He strides with chuffed and chortling stride,  
To greet the smile his kin adore;  
No more the sneerwisp shadows bide,  
As joy returns to hearth and door.  

6  
And thus our hero parts the track,  
His heart agleam with embergloam;  
He casts one glance, returns not back—  
Upon the dusk-lit platform ground.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Inkbrayer Chase

While vellum gloams in twilight seas,  
Beware the Inkbrayer’s crafty chase;  
It spreads its dread on blank decrees,  
And drags the swift in dark caprice.

Unsheathe your quill with steely grace,  
Sharpen its tip to pierce the haze;  
Brace every stroke with vigilant might,  
For inky perils stalk the night.

Behold the Scrawlithawk’s grim glare,  
It parts the dark with deadly mien;  
A splosh-skrill echoes on silent air,  
And parchments shudder at the scene.

The brayer hisses “frazzle-growl” fierce,  
Its roughed rampage of dark contrives;  
Your steadfast stroke then whets and drives,  
To quell the sprawling inktide fierce.

Now homeward fare through scroll and gate,  
Your works gleam sharp in steady frame;  
No lingering dread upholds your fate,  
As dawn unbars the inky flame.

So laud the tale where stories race,  
With quill in hand to hold its pace;  
Let every line your courage trace,  
While vellum gloams in twilight seas.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
Summit Prayer-Pennant

Beware the summit’s prayer-pennant bold,  
That flutters fierce in gale-born gloom,  
In whifflewind and bluster-cold,  
It murmurs rites to stormcloud’s loom.  

Arm your heart with chant and steel,  
Bind your hope in torchlit charms,  
Stand unshaken as you kneel,  
Protected by those sacred arms.  

Then from the murk a peakbeast springs,  
With crestwraith eyes that burn like coal,  
It snaps its flame on tethered strings,  
And sough-song sears the pilgrim’s soul.  

With windknife raised in lightning’s charge,  
You hew the glare to ember-dust,  
The beast convulses, dark and large,  
And shrivels ’neath your steadfast trust.  

Now homeward tread beneath the sky,  
The summit’s prayer-pennant sways,  
Once echoing a fearsome cry,  
It hums in dawn’s forgiving rays.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Soundpost Sprite

Beware the snapping soundpost sprite!  
That lurks beneath violin seam,  
It glimmers slow in candlelight,  
And shatters every wavering dream.  

With luthier’s tools I gird my hand,  
Adjust the brace with tempered zeal,  
My soundpost setter keen at stand,  
To combat dread with crafted steel.  

Then from the scrollwork gloom there blew  
A fretflitter with whirring wing,  
It shrieked “thwock-thwock” as echoes grew,  
And made the silent chambers ring.  

I grasped the iron-riveted brace,  
Then poised the setter, poised to strike,  
It sang “plink-plink!” in hallowed space,  
As steel met wood with fateful might.  

Rejoice! The hollow voice inspires,  
In thrilled harmonies our hearts unite,  
No more shall doubt corrupt our fires—  
Beware the snapping soundpost sprite!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "night‑blooming cereus vigil". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
Night-Blooming Cereus Vigil

1  
Beware the moon-hung cereus cry,  
It drifts when midnight breezes nigh;  
Its ghost-white bloom enchants the sky,  
And lures the timid hearts nearby.

2  
Gird thy nerves with dusk-laced resolve,  
And stow vial of glintwine near;  
Let thornshields braced by moonbeams solve  
A ward ’gainst petals drenched in fear.

3  
At hushful hour the bloombeast sighs,  
Its petalfeast quivering chant;  
It rustles—shh!—through dark and vies  
To bind thy will with spectral pant.

4  
With petalfang and steel-edged glance,  
Thy blade shall pierce its trembling core;  
Its lumacombs of gleam entrance  
Till bloomsnare quails forevermore.

5  
Now homeward through the bleary ways,  
Thy fragrant trophy no more dry;  
Recall this night’s entrancing phase—  
Beware the moon-hung cereus cry.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Modular Spaghettipatch

Beware the patch of tangle-skein,  
Where sinewy cables writhe and coil,  
And snafgle-knots in neon rain  
Will steal the spark of each bold toiler.  

Take up your knobs and crank the key,  
Strike sound-dial thrums in timbral gleam;  
Set blorp-emblems for sync decree,  
And prime your glint of flanger dream.  

Through cable-forest dark and deep,  
Spaghettron coils in snarl and hiss;  
Its twisty sinews wake to creep,  
With birftle-riffs in tangled bliss.  

Then madness-spikes phase amassed  
Leapt forth in ledge of glow-swirl flame;  
You thrust the crystal burn at last,  
And banish’d twist of snaky name.  

Home bled your foot through glimmered glade,  
Your signals hum in triumph clear;  
No patch of coil shall haunt your shade,  
No sprawl of wire shall feed your fear.  

Return to patch of tangle-skein,  
Where neon rain drips calm and slow;  
No cable-coil shall choke again,  
And toilers wake with gentled glow.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "cassette wow and flutter". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Cassette Wow and Flutter

Twas flickling, and the hissful reels,  
Did whirr and wobble in the deck;  
All quaverous were the fluttergrawl eels,  
And tapegrooves sighed in mottled speck.  

Beware the fluttergrawl, my friend,  
The wowksnap’s whirrling on the prowl;  
Beware the hissnor’s savage bend,  
And dread its tinny growl!  

He seized the sturdy pencil-core,  
And primed the chrome-clad platter;  
He wound the reels in careful chore,  
Then hushed the deck’s faint clatter.  

Out slithered-zoom the fluttergrawl,  
Its whirrling spokes in phantom gleam;  
It hissed and snicked a tinny bawl,  
And pulsed through tape-web dream.  

He clicked his pencil-tracker true,  
And carved a splice through buzzing vein;  
The hissnor shrieked its hollow cue,  
Then crumbled in warped remain.  

He strode with platter hum endowed,  
His triumph rich in softened chime;  
The wobble-wound now smooth and bowed,  
Restored to gentle time.  

Twas flickling, and the hissful reels,  
Did whirr and wobble in the deck;  
Yet quaverous were hushed the grawl eels,  
And tapes knew no more fleck.

poem:
The Opal-Flash

1  
Beware the opal-flash’s gleam,  
Its prismglean enchants the midnight air;  
It lures the soul with ghostly beam,  
And spins the wary mind in brume and flare.  

2  
You arm your soul with sharddrift bright,  
And wield the flashblade in moon’s pale light;  
A cloak of shimmer-sheen guards thought,  
Against the glamorfleck’s beguiling spot.  

3  
Atop the dune, the opalwyrm reclines,  
Its prism-hues in glint-glow shiver high;  
It hisses crackle-snap of spectral spines,  
While emeralddusk ignites the starry sky.  

4  
With steely chord and heart aflare you spring,  
Your flashblade cleaves its prism-dazzled face;  
It writhes in crackle-sigh before the sting,  
And glimmersigh subsides in silent space.  

5  
Homeward you stride with opal-glow agleam,  
Held captive now is prismglean once wild and fair;  
You mine the lesson from the spectral dream—  
Beware the opal-flash’s gleam.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "peony ants at dawn". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
Peonyants at Dawn

Hark to the peonyants at dawn,  
Frimble brood swarms on blushing lawn.  
Clatter-clang and wild flitter-fuss,  
Creeping webs bright with glitter-muss.  

Arm thee with your bright silver spade,  
Grip firm the trusty dawn-cut blade.  
Fasten gauntlets, steadfast hand,  
Stand bold and guard the tender land.  

Through pink and soft emerald sod,  
He pressed where leads the silent trod.  
There stands the grim peonyant hoard,  
Slicing blooms with their rusting swords.  

With swish and skrrt the young heart flies,  
He cleaves the swarm with battle cries.  
Each frugglestamp, bold bramble-thwack,  
He smites them down till none come back.  

Now gilded rays embrace the lawn,  
Their tender glow by sunrise drawn.  
The creatures’ threat is now all gone,  
Hark—no peonyants at dawn.

poem:
Oscillobloom

When oscillo waves mystic bloom,  
Beware the gleebridge sprawl;  
The sinewraith stirs scope-lit gloom,  
With sproing, blurp, cackle-call.  

His wavo-saber gleamed at night,  
With sine-cords primed for might;  
He donned his scope-cap mask of light,  
To quell sinewraith fight.  

Atop the crystal scopescreen bloom,  
Whirr and zraiiing sharp crash;  
Out leapt the grim lissabloom froom,  
While gloam-eyes lashed in bash.  

He swung his wavo-saber keen,  
With glint of scope-spark sheen;  
The lissabloom foomed sine-wave mean,  
Its coil-horns curled in green.  

Triumphant he returned to hall,  
Yet whispers trailed his roam;  
His tale proclaimed sinewraith call,  
And soothed each scope at home.  

Peace settles through the circuits’ loom,  
Soft hum replaces each doom;  
Thus dawns a calm after wild gloom,  
When oscillo waves mystic bloom.

poem:
The Civetnote and Drydown

I  
Beware the Civetnote’s sly hiss  
It scrawls its essence on the air  
Its furreze purr will beguile brows  
And drydown drifts you unaware  

II  
Armed with pommadine and pure musk  
The scentsmith treads the dew-kissed vale  
She stirs the essences of husk  
To track the phantom’s scented trail  

III  
At eve she hears a furreze sigh  
A pungent quip in moonlit glow  
Its lodger eyes of amber cry  
Where quiet candle-whispers flow  

IV  
With skrick and smack she snares the ghost  
Her vial drinks the twixt-scent breath  
The gobbrous blob retreats in steam  
As drydown dawns in perfumed gleam  

V  
Back home she hums the civet’s tune  
Her copper flask swells scented pride  
And drips the drift of drydown’s boon  
Beware the Civetnote’s sly hide

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Reglet in the Furniture

1  
Beware the Reglet in the hall,  
Its rustling claw sets curtains rill;  
Its gnarl-grip claws the oaken wall,  
And shivers echo nightly chill.  

2  
Grab spindle-lamp and ward-bound spear,  
Don quilted cloak of burnished plume;  
Stand fast as shadows coil and leer  
Beside the antique couch of gloom.  

3  
Through couch-grim jaws the Reglet prowls,  
Its velvet pads go clank and thunk;  
It shudders drapes with moonlit growls,  
And tapestry murk blooms subkrunk.  

4  
At last the hero grips the blade,  
Brandishing gleaming spindle-spear;  
He cleaves the beast ’neath cushioned spade,  
And rends its roar in crimson smear.  

5  
Now echo comes of silent pall,  
Soft chairs stand still past midnight’s call;  
No rustle breathes in chamber’s seam,  
Beware the Reglet in the hall.

<C1_think>Title line present before first stanza: "The Reglet in the Furniture" is clearly separated from stanzas.</C1_think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "old piton scar". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Piton Scarwyrm

Upon the crag’s old piton scar,  
A scarwyrm stirs in husk of stone;  
Its spallion gaze shall freeze the bone,  
Beware the nightshade sigh it moans!

Steady your pick, that iron tongue,  
Whose clink and clatter haply sung;  
Grip tight the belay, intone song,  
And steel your heart for perils strong.

Then from the crevice, scarwyrm leers,  
A hissing hoard of charn and flame;  
With thrum-thrum beat of ancient fears,  
It sways and skirrs in wild acclaim.

I cleft my blade with crash and flare,  
The scarwyrm roared its sulk and hiss;  
With crack-clash strike I split its lair,  
Till silence pooled where terror is.

Home bound I trace that hoary track,  
Through glimmerglow of dawn’s first scar;  
I hear again the clinking pack,  
And dream of heights I wandered far.

Upon the crag’s old piton scar,  
Soft winds recount each whispered tale;  
I guard its hush from near and far,  
Till dawn revives the climbing gale.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "loom shuttle pick". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Loomshuttle Pick

I  
In the loom of shuttle-pick,  
Heed not the thread of whisper-snick;  
For dim-lit warp and weary weft  
Conceal the hush of weaver-click.  

II  
By flickerflax and warp-bright band,  
Grasp the gleamblade of silken aid;  
Slip on your quillowear, splicetanned,  
And steel your will for threading raid.  

III  
Then sprang the Shuttlewyrm in gleam and ash,  
Unfurled its coil in ember-sash;  
It roared a spindlesnarl of dread,  
And bound the warp in feather-brash.  

IV  
High swung the gleamblade through turretrift,  
It thundered crashsnore from iron-core;  
The Shuttlewyrm reeled from silver rift,  
And sank its form on ashen floor.  

V  
Rejoice! The weavers hail their saviour,  
Who tamed the dread of endless pick;  
Bright spindle-gold now crowns your favour,  
In the loom of shuttle-pick.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "tinsmith stake song". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Tinsmith’s Stake Song

Once by bristleforge the night did gleam,  
Pale whispers crept from bent and rusted beams;  
Elders spoke of Rotterclad’s grim scheme,  
Its clanks and hisses stirred the smithies’ dreams.  

Hark! The tinsmith did forge a trusty spike,  
His hammers drummed a brassy, bold refrain;  
He hummed of quillspurs keen enough to strike,  
Then cried, “Clang! Stake the bane!” through ironed vein.  

Beneath steel arches loomed the Rotterclad,  
Its sprottle-snout wagged in clanking delight;  
A hiss of sparkfire filled that bristled pad,  
And glimmered eyes sent shivers down the night.  

Bold stepped the smith, his sinewed arm in flight;  
He drove the tinspike through Rotterclad’s scaled snare;  
A crinkle-scree! rang out with fractured light,  
Then hush of smelted doom hung heavy in the air.  

Triumphant he strode through bristleforge’s door,  
Folk exulted in his victory roar;  
Their cheers once stirred the moonlit forges’ gleam—  
Once by bristleforge the night did gleam.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pietra dura inlay". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Shardling of Pietra Dura

1.  
Beware the shardling that shatters the stone,  
It flits through tesselloom halls well-known,  
With flornish claws and brily bones,  
It gnaws at marble’s heart with moan.  

2.  
Armed with chisel and duvrel grit,  
A master gears for chipscrawl fit,  
He trims the striated seam,  
He primes each slab for glinting gleam.  

3.  
Lo! Out springs the murasliver fiend,  
With skritch and clatter its rage unseamed,  
The brystone beast on slabs does dance,  
It heedless snaps at every chance.  

4.  
He calls a dulcet tink-tink charge,  
Then carves the crack with studious marge,  
Chip by chip the filament lies,  
A gleaming onlaywer prize.  

5.  
Now halls rejoice in marble sheen,  
Where duvrel grit met crafted been,  
The shardling stilled by temper’d stone,  
Beware the shardling that shatters the stone.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blue hour on snow". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Blue Hour on Snow

1.  
Twas the blue hour on snow so bright,  
Flecks did skitter like gleaming sparks;  
A shrouded hush cloaked creeping night,  
Foretelling dread in frimblenarks.  

2.  
Beware the lorewhump’s sullen call,  
Wield brisk chasms under frost’s sting;  
On hoary winds the blinkfrosts fall,  
So steel your heart and fangshard bring.  

3.  
Through shadow-shrouded birchwood trod,  
Each step a crisp-crackle echo clear;  
Midst bleached boughs shone the lorivod,  
Its yawning maw of whiskerhear.  

4.  
From chasm deep a roar did rise,  
The lorewhump’s eyes all emberfed;  
It lunged with snarl of frostful cries,  
And flakes of crysnort danced o’erhead.  

5.  
With heave and slash of fangshard keen,  
The sleetfurred beast at last went still;  
A hush unbound the whitest scene,  
Save whum-whistle’s distant shrill.  

6.  
Now home I tread where hearths alight,  
Safe from the dusk’s unbroken throe;  
All calmed beneath the silver sight—  
Twas the blue hour on new-fallen snow.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "crosstie creosote scent". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Crosstie Creosote Scent

O heed the scent of crosstie smoke,  
That drifts where midnight sleepers lie;  
Beware the coil of Creoxwyrm’s yoke,  
Whose reeking breath can turn men shy.

Then grip your spiresteel blade aright,  
And gird your stout smokescoured shield;  
Let drift-packs hum with luster bright  
To pierce the mists that veil the field.

Across the creosoted ties we tread,  
The iron rails go clang and clatter;  
Through squealpuff fog and ember-dread,  
We hunt the shade where echoes scatter.

At length we spy a lurid crest,  
Adorned with scale and twisted spire;  
It rears a hiss on burning breast,  
Its roar a rasp that chills the mire.

With clam-clang cry our blades converge,  
We cleave its maw with fervid steel;  
The Creoxwyrm trembles, bones diverge,  
And spills its heart in smoky reel.

Now home we haste by rail’s faint glow,  
Our banners streaked with soot and gore;  
The town awakes to lamp-lit show,  
Where peace endures on crosstie shore.

O heed the scent of crosstie smoke,  
That drifts where midnight sleepers lie;  
Fear still the coil of Creoxwyrm’s yoke,  
Whose embers haunt the rail-swept sky.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "balance spring collet". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Springcollet’s Balance

1.  
Beware the Springcollet’s bursting coil,  
Its bristly sprawl of shnicketed thorn;  
It spins with winding, whirring, wicked toil,  
And glooms the glade before the mournful morn.  

2.  
And take your gleaming balancer’s blade,  
Whose silver spine spits crimson sparks so stark;  
With steady hand through ghost-lit undershade,  
You’ll carve the coil from bramble’s haunted dark.  

3.  
Then tread with caution ‘neath the cryptic fern,  
Where springcollet coils its fierce glinting crease;  
Its tail aflame with mordant sparks that burn,  
To snare the bold within its sharp caprice.  

4.  
Yet grasp your blade with fearless, surging might,  
And flash it down through coil and carven tomb;  
With loud, ringing clang and thunderous smite,  
You lay the fiend to sweet, unholy doom.  

5.  
Then homeward through the bracken-burrowed dell,  
Your heart afire with victory’s keen song;  
The folk will cheer as triumph bells will knell,  
And Springcollet’s bold tale shall join the throng.  

6.  
Beware the Springcollet’s bursting coil,  
Lest balance slip and ruin soon unfold;  
Yet life’s grand art lies in bold, poised turmoil,  
And fortune crowns the daring and the bold.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pantograph arcing blue". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Pantograph Arcing Blue

Beware the pantograph arcing blue,  
Its glinting girts of whirblim light;  
With sparking spokes that rend the dew,  
It prowls the rails at dead of night.  

Armed with sparkshank and mirksteel shield,  
He clasped his gleaming blade of gold;  
Through glintspur gloom he strode the field,  
Prepared to prove his mettle bold.  

From iron hunt the Pantagryph sprang,  
Its clank-claw cleft the night in two;  
The rails did quake as cables sang,  
With whir and zing of flickered blue.  

He raised the lumicutter keen,  
A thunder slash that cleft the gloom;  
It sliced the coils of arcadine unseen,  
And saw the monster meet its doom.  

So home he strode through orchard dew,  
His legend cast in pulse-lit blue;  
In hearth and hall the saga grew anew,  
Beware the pantograph arcing blue.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Murmuration over Stubble

In dawn’s hush over stubblegleam fields,  
Skirrwhirr shoals trace silver arcs in air;  
While flitterbent whispers drift where shadow yields,  
And winged thrums stir slumber from their lair.  

Beware the Skudderwraith that skims the night,  
Its flinching eyes aglow with ravenous dread;  
It saps the courage of hearts set swift to flight,  
And leaves pale ash where boldest dreams have bled.  

Take thrumbore spear with silver tip held high,  
And gird your cliffclad belt with silent zeal;  
Hear clang and clack as dawn stirs the sky,  
Then steel your heart for the dreaded ordeal.  

Atop the stubble the Skudderwraith soared,  
Its skreeing winds gouging trembling dawn’s thin air;  
Through flusterwave groans the wide sky roared,  
And mortals quailed beneath its furious glare.  

You lunged with marrowhilt through flustered gloom,  
Flickerflash seared its vamp‐shed sight;  
In one bold stroke you cleft its brooding doom,  
As Skudderwraith sank into silent night.  

With skirrwhirr call the winged hosts ascend,  
Their silken dance fills dawn’s triumphant air;  
Your steps are light where shadows meet their end,  
In dawn’s hush over stubblegleam fields.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pewter inlay ribbon". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Pewter Inlay Ribbon

Hark, brave souls, the pearly pewter inlay,  
Crinkle-whish glitters at dusk’s dim shore;  
Fend the crimblen wyverns that flay,  
Lest their scrabbling claws rend you evermore.  

Grasp silverbane rapier girded tight,  
Tie scrimblecord ’round wrist and might;  
Sprinkle lodestone dust by ghostly light,  
Brace your heart at the ribbon’s sight.  

From gloam there slinks the Ribbgrin beast,  
Its whisk-whack jaws do fang and fling;  
Dark boughs in wrimsh and crackle cease,  
While briznawks trill in moonlit ring.  

With hilt aloft and a clarion cry,  
You slash the sinew, sund’ring bone;  
A clang—then hush—mid midnight sky,  
The beast lies bound on mossy throne.  

You tread the mortal path once more,  
The forest stilled, its terrors spent;  
In dawn’s calm gleam your heart does store,  
The ribbon’s pewter rune content.  

Now tales shall warn of gleam and fray,  
Where scrimblecord and steel entwine;  
Thus shall your legend bravely stay,  
Hark, brave souls, the pearly pewter inlay.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "linocut brayer chatter". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Brayerchatter

Printle stirred in linocut chatter,  
The brayer hummed its buzzing schemes;  
All cuttal brushes bristled after,  
The flethry ink’s awakening gleams.  

Beware the grim Bratterchomp’s cold jaw,  
With snick-snach bite and gnashing roar;  
Its clattering maw that shudders law  
Will trap your print on ghostly floor.  

He took his briver blade so keen,  
And buckled scrive with aged grieves;  
Through gloaming wood and shadows lean,  
He traced the snorble-pathway weaves.  

At last the Bratterchomp did loom,  
It chittered deep a rattling boom;  
Its fangèd claws split print and gloom,  
Then all grew still as waiting tomb.  

He poised his brayer-bright briver high,  
Snick-snach! The terror met its fall;  
A flush of triumph kissed the sky,  
And echoed wide a victory call.  

Triumphant back to printly home,  
He told the tale in cheer and shout;  
His brayer-whirr and scrive-song roam,  
As linocut lanes rang out.  

Printle stirred in linocut chatter,  
The brayer hummed its buzzing schemes;  
All cuttal brushes bristled after,  
And flethry ink resumed its gleams.

poem:
The Quarter-Sawn Shimmer

When dovetail dusk meets quarter-sawn shimmer,  
Beware the glimblight gleam;  
Its shiv’ring lurkle floods the wood with shimmer,  
O hearts of iron, dream!  

He seized his quarter-glaive with shining pride,  
His heart aflame in valor rare;  
He strode through glimmerwold with stalwart pride,  
In quest of perils most rare.  

Before him loomed the dread giant Quarter-sawn Shimmer,  
A barky bane with flicker-flame;  
Its boughs brusque-rustled rang through shimmering shimmer,  
It hissed the doom of flame.  

He smote the boughs with shimmer-snack, crack!  
The wood-heart cracked then split;  
Till Quarter-sawn Shimmer reeled at final crack,  
And hushed its timber-soul split.  

Now hearts rejoice with ember-glow and tide,  
In triumph’s realm of pure shimmer;  
Through glade and grove he bore the tide,  
At quarter-sawn shimmer.

poem:
Blued-Screw Charm

I  
Hark to the hum of blued-screw charm,  
That whirls its gleam in sable gloom;  
Beware the grozzle’s dire alarm,  
And snerdle-snout that feasts on doom.  

II  
Grip tight thy snicker-sheath-ed blade,  
Don bramble-coil of iron-wham;  
Let crackleclasp and gear-shield aid,  
To thwart the brabble-fang’s mad cram.  

III  
At break of snell, the grozzle-sneep,  
That brangle-snout and cog-ears churn;  
Thy gear-glaive arcs through brume so deep,  
To woodle-split its feral spurn.  

IV  
Rejoice! Thy bramble-coil still sings,  
And configury bears its charm;  
The grozzle-kin resigns its wings,  
Hark to the hum of blued-screw charm.

poem:
Parrel Bead on a Gaff

High on the parrel bead of gaff,  
where salt-laced breezes coil and heave,  
The skortchling stirs its bristle-staff;  
You’d best beware ere waters cleave.

Draw the scarlet windsaber sheath,  
where thrum and crackling echoes seethe;  
Slide the blade through coppered wreath,  
Brace your sinew, shielded beneath.

From murky fog the Skortchling springs,  
With snarling crack and spurting growls;  
Its talons curled in warlit rings,  
It lunges forth on crushing growls.

I swung the blade in argent flame,  
It gasped a “fwoom!” then screeching clash;  
Its jagged form returned no name,  
Its maw went hollow—then sharp crash.

Now home we drift from battered craft,  
Our story told in whispered half;  
With Skortchling’s tale etched on our shaft,  
High on the parrel bead of gaff.

Beware the Glimmergrim

1.  
Beware the glimmergrim at dusk,  
Its spareslush breath will leave you weak,  
Father spoke low, his beard all musk,  
“Arm with levain before you seek.”  

2.  
In shadowed bowl the levain feeds,  
Through autolyse and gentle fold,  
I stir until each bubble leads,  
To crumbs more bright than gleaming gold.  

3.  
At midnight stalks the crumbsnatch fiend,  
Its hiss and splish and pop a-gleam;  
It prowls in depths of spongey green,  
To steal your dough and levain’s dream.  

4.  
With blade of lame you face the beast;  
A slash rings swift through spareslush grove;  
The foamshroud brood at last released,  
Regains its glow in dawn’s alcove.  

5.  
Triumphant baker bright returns,  
His levendream a luster’d husk;  
No more the gluten grave he spurns,  
Beware the glimmergrim at dusk.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Sashiko-Boro Patch

1  
At dusk we spied the worn boro patch,  
Its tatters frayed like mournful lace;  
A ragged dread across the thatch,  
Prepared to rend the earth’s embrace.

2  
Beware the fraylark’s cawing screech,  
Its feathered shards of petrol gloom;  
Gather the needles, threads to reach  
The stitched defense against its doom.

3  
From ragged seam a shadow sprang,  
The sashikoth with talons bared;  
It hissed and rumbled, ker-chish clang,  
As lantern glimmer slowly fared.

4  
With satin-thread and steady hand  
We danced the running stitch galore;  
The boro’s myrtle line would stand  
To cleave the fiend forevermore.

5  
Now dawn reveals the mended spread  
No fiend escapes the joined dispatch;  
Restored in grace the cloth lies shed—  
At dusk we spied the worn boro patch.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Nixie Tube Glowwyrm

Beware the Nixie Tube warm glow,  
Its filaments of mystic hue;  
Lest shimmerbeasts from circuits flow  
And steal the spark that lies in you.

Armed with a neon-scythe you tread,  
Clad in glow-welded mail of wires;  
Set circuits buzzing, warding dread,  
And charge the lance with pulsing fires.

Through crackle-pass and spizwhirr haze,  
Where humgnar skulk in shadowed glows,  
He spies the grim glowwyrm ablaze,  
With hiss-swish tongue attuned to foes.

The neon-scythe sang slash-thunk bright,  
While fizzle-fume enwrapped the fray;  
He cleft the glowwyrm’s fierce core alight,  
And banished dread from wire and bay.

Back through crackle-pass he strode with pride,  
A severed glowwyrm’s filament aglow;  
The humgnar thronged in ringing stride—  
Hark! Behold the Nixie Tube warm glow!

poem:
The Fishtail Gouge Sweep

1  
Beware the dark fishtail gouge sweep,  
Lest ghallamyr lurch down from deep.  
Its quibber-quill will swift hearts leap,  
And pierce your bold resolve to keep.  

2  
With glint and grax your blade prepare,  
Let whissle-whirr tune your keen aim;  
Shield heart and soul from fang and flare,  
And hurl your courage into frame.  

3  
Then from the brine a shim-snap sound  
As ghallamyr’s jaws begin to gape;  
Scale-plates ring with creak profound,  
While salty mists the air reshape.  

4  
Unleash your sharp, fish-fangged lance,  
In vortex swirl of rpash and swoop;  
Pierce sinuous throat in single dance,  
And silence seize the crushing droop.  

5  
Now homeward stride with trophy bright,  
Your heart drum-whump, your spirit leap;  
Sing tales of brave fishtail fight—  
Beware the dark fishtail gouge sweep.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "letter kept in a cedar box". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Cedar-Box Missive

It was gloaming by the cedar box,  
The letter slept ’neath barnquill clasp,  
Heed well the lines that summon shocks,  
Or rue the snick-snap of doom’s grasp.

With quill in pocket, I donned my blade,  
A shimmer-shield of searcleft steel,  
I heard soft thrumble stir night’s cascade,  
And felt a spine-buzzing zeal.

Then churned the lid with a cracking brawl,  
The Boxwyrm writhed with glinting fang,  
A snort-snarl burst within the hall,  
Its gleaming claws set star-sparks rang.

I leaped to thrust my searbane blade,  
And snick-snack cleft its iron hide,  
A clamorous roar the stillness frayed,  
Then silence sank with somber tide.

With box in hand and letter found,  
I strode through dusk to hearthlit halls,  
The cedar scent alive around,  
As moonlight danced on timber walls.

Now tales may fade with parchment dust,  
Yet memory clings to aged box,  
True valor thrives where heart is just,  
It was gloaming by the cedar box.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "Morse straight key click". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Morse-Key Wraith

1  
Beware the click of Morse at night.  
The sly, swift flick of straight-key code;  
Its phantom pulses spark the fright  
Where ghostly twindles roam the node.  

2  
He grasps the iron straight-key bar,  
With laced-up nerves of chrome;  
He girds his chest with brazen jar,  
And scopes his aim by cipherchrome.  

3  
Across the void the Blink-Blight glides,  
It sputters dread in dot-dot-dash;  
Its bulbous form of sparks and tides  
Unfurls a storm in electric flash.  

4  
He hammers taps through steel-bound gleam,  
A thund’ring roar of clack and din;  
He splinters frames of phantom beam,  
And drowns the blight with final din.  

5  
O’er calm-hushed wires the victor treads,  
His steady heart attuned to night;  
The node exhales its sighing threads,  
Beware the click of Morse at night.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "fiddle rosin dust". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Fiddle-Rosin Fray

1  
Beware the fiddle-rosin dust,  
Its crustlewhump will seize your trust;  
The glintwyrm in rosinshroud  
Snarls through the fiddle fuzz aloud.  

2  
Take up your strumple-spear so keen,  
And don the scrimdark cloak serene;  
Spit sizzle-salve on sharpened blade,  
To face the beast in moonlit glade.  

3  
Through frosted fern and thorny boughs,  
A thwump awakes the silent low;  
Again it cries across the boughs,  
Then glintwyrm breathes its fiery blow.  

4  
You hurl the strumple-spear aright,  
It whistles clear through rosinshroud;  
The glintwyrm bursts in searing light,  
Then thud!—its crumbling ruin loud.  

5  
Triumphant, you retrace your way  
Past crustlewhump and fiddle hush;  
With rosin-flecked and weary sway,  
You spurn the echoing glintwyrm’s rush.  

6  
In hearthlit hall the minstrels trust,  
Your tale of dust and daring thrust;  
With fiddle-strains and rosin-lust,  
Beware the fiddle-rosin dust.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plane iron camber". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Plane-Iron Camber

1  
Beware the dread Plane-Iron Camber,  
That skitters ’cross the marbled lea,  
Its serried spokes of steel encamber  
And chills the blood that beats in thee.  

2  
He seized his gleam-sheared skell-light blade,  
And donned his drumble helm of horn;  
Cried “O! I’ll foil that rust-clad raid,”  
Beneath the brume of breaking morn.  

3  
Through rumbling reeds and bellow-brine,  
The clatterbeast its presence showed;  
A hulking bulk of harsh design,  
With jagged jaws and steely load.  

4  
He braced his stance on splintered briar,  
And swift he swung with shudder-shout;  
The sword sang ’neath the metal wire,  
A crunch, a crack—a thunderous rout!  

5  
Then homeward turned the dauntless sprite,  
Through dusky fen and cinder-swept;  
His heart aglow with morning light,  
No shade nor chill could hold him kept.  

6  
And peace returns to marbled lea,  
As songs arise to hail his name;  
No more the beast roams wild and free,  
The dread Plane-Iron Camber’s tame.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "orin bell hum". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Orin-bell Hum

1.  
Beware the Orin-bell hum so,  
Its shrill thrum in twilight’s brim;  
Lest you tread the grawlix glow  
And heed its spectral shrum and whim.  

2.  
Arise, my child, take spandle-sabre keen,  
And gird your helm with starthroop band;  
Let steel and will, resolute, convene  
To guard your heart and steady hand.  

3.  
Through fizzling reeds the pathway curls,  
Past thrumble-trees that shiver-squeech;  
Where moonlight streaks the brustle-whorl,  
And silent shadows creep and screech.  

4.  
Then from the gloom a shape did loom,  
A quivering hum of pulse and purr;  
Its many-peered maw in starlight bloom,  
With gleaming grawlix claws astir.  

5.  
I raised my spandle-sabre high—  
Whish! went the blade through sound and shade;  
The Orin-bell’s last echoing cry  
Fell mute within the moonlit glade.  

6.  
Triumphant back my path I trace,  
With heart unbound by fear or numb;  
The dawn greets home my eager pace,  
Ere shadows hush that former hum.  

7.  
Now daylight breaks you free from numb,  
Yet still the dusk resumes its hum;  
Let watchful souls resist the dumb—  
Beware the Orin-bell hum.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Brinehiss

Beware the quenching brine hiss,  
That curls with misty, moonlit kiss;  
It spreads through fen of foaming dread,  
A whisper on each broken tread.  

Armed with a gleaming shoalspear true,  
He braves the sleebish spume-dark fen;  
His purpose firm as oaken hue,  
To quell the dread of drannock-kin.  

He meets at last the brine-hulk vast,  
Its eyes aglow with frond and slime;  
It hiss-sloshes in a savage blast,  
A terror born of sea and time.  

He lunges in with furrowed might,  
His shoalspear singing steel-like gnash;  
The drannock reels in bleary fright,  
As shards of saline armor crash.  

Now hush the dread that once did hiss,  
His heart now hums with gentle bliss;  
The fen lies draped in pale moon glow,  
Beware now the quenching brine hiss.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "badger knot bloom". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Badgerknot Bloom

1  
Beware the badgerknot bloom,  
That sniffs at moonlit dread,  
Its sprawl will seep with sleeping gloom,  
And tangle all brave tread.  

2  
Take spade and bristle-masked shield,  
Gird waist with staunch stormrind scrip,  
Don brass-bound helm of burnished yield,  
Slake thirst with fizzing hudderdrip.  

3  
Through brumpling bog, shrieklit glade,  
You spy the bloom in bristled chrome,  
Its vine-like sprawl ensnares your shade,  
Its sep’lent sigh calls prowling home.  

4  
Out creeps Badgerknot, jaws agape,  
With snap-snap fangs that make you quake;  
It looms in fierce bristlegnarled shape,  
And gropes your blade to seal the take.  

5  
Raise bristleblade with steady flare,  
Whish-swoosh splits the marrow-core;  
Badgerknot falters, screech-crunch bare,  
As hush-hush dusk brings soft new lore.  

6  
Homeward the bard strides, flag uncurled,  
Though hearts quicken at sundark doom;  
He hums of brights in brumpled world—  
Still beware the badgerknot bloom.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
Nib-Tine Micro-Mesh

Beware the nib-tine micro-mesh,  
Its glimmer traps the bravest bold;  
No hapless stride can break or thresh,  
It weaves its threads in phantom cold.  

Armed with a scrimblish blade and brand,  
Sir Calderon honed his keen resolve;  
He draped a cloak of star-spun sand,  
And vowed to make the menace dissolve.  

At murk of eve the Meshrumph did soar,  
His flithering wings a sizzle-hum;  
Sir Calderon loosed a nib-tine lore,  
And cleft the mesh where shadows come.  

Triumphant home he steered through midnight’s crest,  
Beyond the vale where phantom webs enmesh;  
He hums the tale of one fated conquest,  
And warns anew: beware nib-tine micro-mesh!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "krenovian plane throat". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Beware the Krenovian Plane-Throat

1  
Beware the Krenovian Plane-Throat, my son,  
Its slorping roar through spherous mists will wind;  
No glimshroud’s glow can tame its grashful run,  
Or quell the flutt’ring fray it leaves behind.  

2  
Arise at dawn and gird your vorpblade tight,  
Don vesped mail where gleaming veins ignite;  
Sip bramblebrew to steel your trembling heart,  
And heed the sphem horn’s clear and steady start.  

3  
Through yesterwood you tred the duskened way,  
Each footfall throbs in murren’s muted thrum;  
The Plane-Throat gleams beneath that baleful fray,  
Its flaring eyes a furious snapping drum.  

4  
Then swooped the fiend with throat of sickly flash,  
Its jaws agape in lurching, musty clash;  
It slurped in stutch with rumbling, rasping spit,  
Its horrid groan all scraped with bristling grit.  

5  
You swung your gleam-scythe in a sudden flare,  
Its throat unleashed a jagged, grinding roar;  
It staggered, slick with blood and molten gore,  
Then stilled its breath in one last haggard blare.  

6  
You turned toward hearth and hall with weary mind,  
Your cloak in brambleblood and vesped dight;  
The sphem horn’s call at last rang sweet and kind,  
And chased away the cark of endless night.  

7  
Beware no more the Krenovian Plane-Throat, son,  
Its slorping horror sunk in brambled clay;  
Return with tales of valiant deeds well won,  
And watch its glibbered dread to shadows stray.

poem:
Patter on the Tinroof

Patter on the tinroof, hark!  
Beware the Dratterjack’s fierce din;  
Its raindrop blades in shadows dark  
Will set your pulses in a spin.  

Clutch your echo-brella tight,  
To banish drippet-spatter-storm;  
Don tinfoil helm through howling night,  
With wind-sheath gauntlets strong and warm.  

Then sweeps the silver-sabled host  
With plinkling arms and steely squall;  
You thrust the spatterfiend its boast,  
And through its drizzled heart you gall.  

At dawn you stand while mists unlace,  
The battered battleground lies stark;  
Your breath resumes in soft embrace,  
Patter on the tinroof, hark!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sencha kyusu drip". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Sencha Kyusu Drip

Beware the Sencha Kyusu Drip, O friend,  
That sizzles softly with a serpentine hiss;  
It coils in silent steam, a sly archbend,  
And whispers woes with every dribbled kiss.  

Take up your kyusu, stout and grainy clay,  
Fill with emerald leaves of swift senchay;  
Steep them gently ’neath the crimson cup,  
Hear plink-plink promise as the drip winds up.  

From hidden nook emerges Drimloop stark,  
His slurping jaws aglaze with molten brew;  
His fur is laced with mist of ocher dew,  
A kazoo-roar rattles deep within the dark.  

Then raise aloft your vessel, brimming high,  
And pour the steaming tide upon his maw;  
As splosh and spatter bind his path in awe,  
And set his sizzle-sorrow free to cry.  

Now safe you tread through dawn’s soft saffron light,  
With vessel warmed by conquered, silken sip;  
Yet guard your cup from creeping phantom night,  
Lest you succumb to Sencha Kyusu Drip.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "split‑grade enlarger burn". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Spligrade Burn

Beware the Spligrade Burn, dear friend,  
Its fractafire flares at each turn;  
Through grondered glooms its embers rend,  
And scorch the souls that yearn to learn.

Unsheath thy bevel-blade and brightron shield,  
Let rim-root cord hold firm thy stand;  
Through gloom-torn halls the echoes yield,  
And steel thy nerves at their command.

Beneath the metal-smoke of charmed spire,  
Trace the hiss-sizzled paths of brass;  
Mid murk and brim of embered mire,  
Where cobbled grunge and molten mass.

At last the lurken shellhulk comes to brawl,  
With brank-spikes jagged and cruel claws;  
Hear grounced moans from caverned wall,  
And skrrk-scratch growls that give you pause.

Then clasp the fractaslice of brondwood spark,  
And cleave the burniferous maw;  
Till sizzle-roar rends the stark-black dark,  
And halts the shellhulk’s draw.

When brondwood spark fades to dawn’s pale gleam,  
And brank-spikes shatter pale;  
Thou bear’st the charred fragment of dream,  
And heed the embers’ tale.

Stand well apart from cinder’d urn,  
Where restless echoes warn you, friend;  
E’er dare approach the Spligrade Burn—  
Beware the Spligrade Burn, dear friend.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "kiridashi scribe line". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Kiridashi Scribe Line

Kiridashi scribe line gleams  
Beneath gloaming’s pearled abyss  
Beware the Scribblinwyrm’s dark schemes  
Whose snuffle-huffs birth shrieking hiss  

He drew his keen kiridashi blade  
And buckled inkhoarded mail  
His glimmerclasp and quillet made  
To pierce the Wyrm’s dark-verdig veil  

Through sprawlagon’s bristling pall  
He strode with purpose, undeterred  
Where drumble-thrush did whirr and trill  
Amid the gloaming’s whispered word  

Upon a mossy scribble-thorn  
The Scribblinwyrm uncoiled and leered  
Its glimmergash all fury-torn  
Spittled-spume on stone appeared  

Then clang and thwack rang wide and clear  
As kiridashi pierced each scale  
He struck with unmatched, fearless cheer  
And bade the wyrm to final wail  

He bore the head of scribblin wyrm  
Through gloaming glade to kin allied  
Their glimmerglow did quell each squirm  
While mirthful huzzah swelled far and wide  

Rejoice! The gloaming’s dread now gone  
Their hearts aglow with shining gleams  
Our tale resounds, its roar lives on  
Kiridashi scribe line gleams
